Award.AwardTitle: First International Mathematics Teacher Education Study (TEDS-M)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will study how teachers of mathematics are prepared across 40 countries that are part of the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA) network. Specifically, the study will address the following questions:

1. What is the level and depth of the mathematics and related teaching knowledge attained by prospective primary and lower secondary teachers that enables them to teach the kind of demanding mathematics curricula currently found in the higher achieving countries?
2. What learning opportunities available to these prospective teachers enable them to attain such knowledge?
3. What are the intended and implemented policies that support these teachers' achieved level and depth of mathematics and related teaching knowledge? How do teacher policies influence the structure of their opportunities to learn mathematics at national and institutional levels?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Teacher Education and Development Study in Mathematics or TEDS-M is a pioneering study that documented across countries how primary and secondary teachers of mathematics are prepared. The participating countries are part of the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA) network.

 

The TEDS-M study addressed the following questions.

 

(1)    What is the level and depth of the mathematics and related teaching knowledge attained by prospective primary and lower secondary teachers that enables them to teach the kind of demanding mathematics curricula currently found in the higher achieving countries?

 

(2)    What learning opportunities available to prospective primary and lower secondary mathematics teachers allow them to attain such knowledge?

 

(3)    What are the intended and implemented policies that support primary and lower secondary teachers’ achieved level and depth of mathematics and related teaching knowledge?

 

Intellectual merit. TEDS-M addresses key questions related to improving the education of primary and lower secondary mathematics teachers. We looked deliberately at content-specific issues by making mathematics a central focus of the study.  We used knowledge for mathematics teaching as a key construct, making this a study about teachers’ knowledge, not only about their paper credentials. We explored how policies inform and shape practice in teacher education for mathematics teaching. Thus, policy becomes a subject for study, not just context. These dimensions set the study apart, and their combination makes the study ambitious and cutting edge. 

 

Broader impacts. The results of this study: (a) help to strengthen the knowledge base to address current national priorities such as increasing the number of fully competent mathematics teachers in the U.S.; (b) gather empirical data on the experience of the U.S. and other countries to help resolve conflicts over the nature, benefits and costs of teacher education; (c) further a more scientific approach to the study of teacher education and teacher learning in mathematics; and (d) develop a common language, concepts, measurement strategies, indicators and instrumentation to strengthen the research in this field, and the knowledge base of teacher education cost-effectiveness.

 

Outcomes. The impetus for TEDS-M, was the recognition that teaching in general, and specifically in the so-called STEM subjects, has become more challenging worldwide, as growth in knowledge demands frequent curricular change and as large numbers of teachers reach retirement age. Effectively responding to demands for teacher preparation reform will remain difficult while there is lack of consensus on what such reform should encompass. TEDS-M accordingly focused on collecting empirical data that could inform policy and practice related to recruiting and preparing a new generation of teachers capable of teaching increasingly demanding mathematics curricula.

Although future teachers and school systems must place their trust in the numerous and diverse teacher education programs across the world, no comprehensive, authoritative study of the outcomes of teacher education had been carried out at the time that the TEDS-M study took place, and none has been done since. The lack of work in this area made it essential to do a comprehensive study of teacher education’s immediate outcomes to identify what knowledge, skills and, dispositions future teachers have close to graduation and when they are declared ready to teach.

The information collected came from representative samples of preservice teacher education programs in 17 countries including the United States, Chinese Taipei, Germany, Poland, the Russian Federation, and Singapore. Programs, future teachers and program teaching staff were surveyed.

The main TEDS-M findings are well-documented in the seven reports which can be found on the IEA website (http://www.ilsa-gateway.org/ searching by study ‘TEDS-M’), in the ERIC system and in various several articles, special journal issues and books.

The TEDS-M data is publicly available: TEDS-M 2008 international database.

In 2018, Springer will publish a new book with contributions from young scholars that were nurtured by the TEDS-M team. Writing and data analysis workshops supported the development of ideas and eventually resulted in 12 original chapters:

Tatto, M.T., Rodriguez, M., Smith, W. Reckase, M. & Bankov, K. (Eds.) (forthcoming in 2018). Exploring the mathematics education of teachers using TEDS-M data. Netherlands, Dordrecht: Springer.

The question of how teacher preparation programs can achieve the desired outcomes for future mathematics teachers continues to be a high priority in the U.S. and around the globe. The results of TEDS-M show that rigorous selection strategies where priority is given to possessing an acceptable college level of mathematical knowledge, high quality opportunities to learn school-relevant mathematical and mathematical pedagogical knowledge, and research-based accreditation standards make a difference.

Because the TEDS-M study enabled mathematics teacher educators to collect data on their own practices and program outcomes, this study is particularly relevant to current policy priorities in the U.S. and globally and it responds to the need to develop valid and reliable methods to evaluate the effectiveness of mathematics teacher preparation programs in a way that is conducive to continuous program self-study and improvement.
